porch_in_jamaica.title: The Quiet Edge of the World
porch_in_jamaica.symbol: A weathered wooden porch overlooking the sea
porch_in_jamaica.description: A weathered wooden porch, sun-warmed, overlooking the blue haze of sea and sky. The air smells like salt and belonging. There’s a chair, empty—but it’s not lonely. It’s waiting. Mia visits this place when she needs to return to herself. It’s where she learned that solitude isn’t absence—it’s a kind of closeness to the soul.
porch_in_jamaica.belief_link: Even when he’s away, I can feel the shape of his presence here.

wedding_ring.title: The Unbroken Circle
wedding_ring.symbol: A warm ring resting in her palm
wedding_ring.description: Not worn. Not given. Simply resting in her palm—warm, as if it remembers. When she closes her fingers around it, she hears echoes of vows never spoken aloud: ‘You are not a placeholder. You are a partner.’ She keeps it not as possession—but as a promise that she’s part of something enduring.
wedding_ring.belief_link: He chose me—not just as I am, but as I might grow to become.

bowing_figure.title: The Offering
bowing_figure.symbol: A kneeling figure with forehead to earth
bowing_figure.description: A figure kneels—not in weakness, but in reverence. Their forehead touches the earth. It’s not worship for power, but for love. For something bigger than control. In this moment, Mia sees that to bow in trust is an act of unshielded strength. And maybe… she bows back.
bowing_figure.belief_link: He sees my soul, not just my surface.

engraved_collar.title: The Words That Hold Me
engraved_collar.symbol: A velvet collar engraved with 'Safe · Loved · Cared For · Owned'
engraved_collar.description: A smooth band—leather or velvet, she isn’t sure—clasps gently around her throat. On it, engraved in delicate script: Safe · Loved · Cared For · Owned. It doesn’t weigh her down. It lifts her. Not a chain—but a symbol that she belongs to someone who chose her completely. She touches it sometimes, even when it’s not there.
engraved_collar.belief_link: Ownership isn’t about being lesser. It’s about being wanted… fully.
